title: Data Communication and Networking - Multiple Choice Questions
subtitle: NIOS Class 12 Computer Science - Module 1: Lesson 5

questions.question: What are the basic elements of a communication system?
questions.explanation: The basic elements of a communication system are: Transmitter (converts information to suitable form), Channel (physical medium for transmission), and Receiver (receives the transmitted information).

questions.question: In which transmission mode can data be sent only in one direction?
questions.explanation: In Simplex transmission mode, data can be sent only in one direction (uni-directional). The receiver can only receive data but cannot communicate back to the sender.

questions.question: Which transmission mode allows data to be sent in both directions but not simultaneously?
questions.explanation: Half Duplex allows data transmission in both directions, but the sender can either receive or send data at a particular time, not both simultaneously.

questions.question: In Full Duplex mode, what is possible?
questions.explanation: Full Duplex is a bi-directional mode where data can be sent in both directions simultaneously. Both sending and receiving can happen at the same time.

questions.question: What characterizes analog transmission?
questions.explanation: In analog transmission, information changes continuously and can take on many different values. It uses a continuous signal to transmit voice, data, image or other information.

questions.question: How is digital transmission characterized?
questions.explanation: Digital transmission is characterized by discrete states. The transmission signal is not continuous but discrete, represented as a series of 0s and 1s.

questions.question: What does E-M Spectrum stand for?
questions.explanation: E-M Spectrum stands for Electromagnetic Spectrum, which is the range of all possible frequencies of electromagnetic radiation.

questions.question: What is the bandwidth capacity of Narrowband?
questions.explanation: Narrowband can accommodate up to 64Kbps, also known as DS-0 (Digital Signal level 0) channel, which is the fundamental increment on which digital networks were built.

questions.question: What is Wideband in terms of bandwidth?
questions.explanation: Wideband is a transmission medium or channel that has a wider bandwidth than the voice channel, i.e., more than 64Kbps.

questions.question: What is the minimum speed for Broadband?
questions.explanation: Technically speaking, broadband has been defined as being anything over 2Mbps. It refers to any type of transmission technique that carries several data channels over a common wire.

questions.question: Which guided transmission media consists of two insulated copper wires twisted together?
questions.explanation: A twisted pair consists of two insulated copper wires, typically about 1 mm thickness, twisted together in a helical shape. These are commonly used in local telephone communication.

questions.question: Which transmission media consists of a stiff copper wire as the core?
questions.explanation: Coaxial cable consists of a stiff copper wire as the core, surrounded by an insulating material. Higher data rates over longer distances can be achieved with coaxial cable.

questions.question: What material is used in the core of optical fiber?
questions.explanation: Each optical fiber has an inner core of glass or plastic that conducts light. It is a flexible transparent fiber made using silica glass.

questions.question: Which transmission media has the slowest transmission speed?
questions.explanation: Twisted pair wire has the slowest transmission speed among the options listed. Fiber optic cable offers the highest speeds.

questions.question: What is a characteristic of microwave transmission?
questions.explanation: In microwave transmission, the waves travel in straight lines. The transmitting and receiving antennas must be accurately aligned with each other.

questions.question: Which type of transmission is omni-directional?
questions.explanation: Radio waves can be broadcasted in all directions from the source (Omni-directional), so transmitter and receiver do not have to be carefully aligned physically.

questions.question: Where are infrared waves commonly used?
questions.explanation: Infrared waves are widely used for short-range communication. The remote controls used on television, VCRs and stereos use infrared communication.

questions.question: What is Bluetooth classified as?
questions.explanation: Bluetooth is a WPAN (Wireless Personal Area Network) technology with low power, short range, and medium transmission speed characteristics.

questions.question: What is the typical range of Bluetooth?
questions.explanation: Bluetooth has short range characteristics, typically around 10 meters, and is designed for low power consumption with medium transmission speeds.

questions.question: What type of network is Wi-Fi?
questions.explanation: Wi-Fi is a Local Area Network (LAN) technology. It offers a 100 meter range with high transmission rates similar to high-speed modems.

questions.question: What is a computer network?
options: A single computer with multiple monitors
Group of interconnected computers that exchange and share information
questions.explanation: A computer network is a group of computers which are interconnected to exchange and share information and resources.

questions.question: What does a modem do?
options: Converts digital to analog and analog to digital
questions.explanation: A modem works in two ways: modulation (converting digital data to analog) and demodulation (converting analog to digital). It provides connectivity with the internet.

questions.question: What does RJ45 stand for?
questions.explanation: RJ stands for 'Registered Jack' since it is a standardized network interface. The '45' refers to the number of the interface standard. It's commonly used for Ethernet networking.

questions.question: What is another name for an Ethernet card?
questions.explanation: Ethernet cards are also known as Network Interface Cards (NICs). These adapters support the Ethernet standard for high-speed network connections via cables.

questions.question: What is the primary function of a router?
options: Forward packets from one logical network to another
questions.explanation: Routers are networking devices used to extend or segment networks by forwarding data packets from one logical network to another. They connect at gateways where two or more networks meet.

questions.question: What is the main limitation of a hub?
options: Broadcasts all network data across each connection
questions.explanation: A hub has no routing intelligence and broadcasts all network data across each connection, which can be a security risk and cause bottlenecks. It increases chances for collision.

questions.question: What advantage does a switch have over a hub?
options: It sends data only to the addressed computer
questions.explanation: A switch can 'learn' where particular addresses are and repeat incoming data frames only to the addressed computer, making the network more efficient than a hub.

questions.question: What must a switch be able to read from each frame?
questions.explanation: A switch must be able to read the MAC address of each frame it receives. This information allows switches to send data only to the correct destination.

questions.question: What is a gateway used for?
options: Connecting networks using the same protocol
questions.explanation: A network gateway is used to connect networks using different base protocols. It can be implemented in software, hardware, or both, and operates at the network layer.

questions.question: What is a bridge used for?
options: To separate two or more network segments within one logical network
questions.explanation: A bridge separates two or more network segments within one logical network (e.g., a single IP-subnet). It examines data packets and decides whether to pass them to the other segment.

questions.question: What is the geographical area covered by a LAN?
options: Small area like a building or group of buildings
questions.explanation: Local Area Network (LAN) is confined to a small geographical area, like in a building or group of buildings.

questions.question: What is a characteristic of LAN data transfer rate?
options: Very high, even faster than telephone lines
questions.explanation: The data transfer rate of LAN is very high, even faster than data transmitted through telephone lines.

questions.question: What does MAN stand for?
questions.explanation: MAN stands for Metropolitan Area Network, which is basically spread throughout a city, college campus or a small region.

questions.question: Which type of network typically uses public telephone lines and lease lines?
questions.explanation: Wide Area Network (WAN) uses public network telephone lines and lease lines. It covers a comparatively large geographic area, even spanning entire countries or the world.

questions.question: What is the best known example of a public WAN?
questions.explanation: Internet is the best known example of a public WAN (Wide Area Network). WANs provide network to LANs and MANs.

questions.question: What communication medium do WANs typically use?
questions.explanation: Wide Area Networks use optic fiber as their communication medium for high-speed, long-distance data transmission.

questions.question: In Bus topology, how are computers connected?
options: By a single length of cable with terminators at each end
questions.explanation: In Bus topology, all computers are connected by a single length of cable with a terminator at each end. It's the simplest and most widely used LAN design.

questions.question: What is a disadvantage of Bus topology?
options: If main cable fails, entire network fails
questions.explanation: In Bus topology, if the main cable fails, the entire network fails. It's also slower with many devices and only one computer can send a message at a time.

questions.question: In Star topology, what do computers connect to?
questions.explanation: In Star topology, each computer communicates with a central hub that re-sends the message. Every node has a dedicated connection to the central hub.

questions.question: What happens if the host computer fails in Star topology?
questions.explanation: If the host computer (central hub) fails in Star topology, the entire network gets affected. This is a major disadvantage despite its ease of setup.

questions.question: What access method does Token Ring use?
questions.explanation: Token Ring uses token passing as the access method to prevent collision of data between computers. The token ring protocol was developed by IBM.

questions.question: In Ring topology, how is each node connected?
options: Physically to only two adjacent nodes
questions.explanation: In Ring topology, each node is physically connected to only two other nodes. Workstations are connected in a circle forming a logical ring.

questions.question: What is Tree topology also known as?
questions.explanation: Tree topology is also known as Hierarchical topology. It uses two or more star networks connected together and divides the network into multiple levels.

questions.question: Which topology connects each node to at least two other nodes?
questions.explanation: In Mesh topology, each node connects to at least two other nodes. It can be full mesh (every node connected to all others) or partial mesh.

questions.question: What does FTP stand for?
questions.explanation: FTP stands for File Transfer Protocol. It is the most widely used protocol for file transfer over the network using TCP/IP for communication.

questions.question: What does HTTP stand for?
questions.explanation: HTTP stands for Hypertext Transfer Protocol. It works on client-server model and is used to transfer hypertext over the World Wide Web.

questions.question: What is a virus in computer terminology?
options: A program written to enter and damage/alter files/data
questions.explanation: A virus is a program written to enter your computer and damage/alter your files/data. Viruses can also replicate themselves and spread.

questions.question: What is spam?
options: Electronic junk mail - unwanted commercial advertisements
questions.explanation: Spam is electronic junk mail - unwanted commercial advertisements sent to users. Spamming is a method of flooding the Internet with copies of the same message.

questions.question: What is a firewall?
options: Hardware device or software to examine and control network communications
questions.explanation: A firewall is a hardware device or software application installed on the borderline of secured network to examine and control incoming and outgoing network communications, providing protection from outside attacks.

questions.question: What is the purpose of antivirus software?
options: To prevent unwanted and potentially malicious files from entering network
questions.explanation: Antivirus software refers to a group of features designed to prevent unwanted and potentially malicious files from entering your network. It checks for virus signatures and grayware.
